thread.title: Can we play you every week? Inside the world's smallest football league, which contains just TWO teams
thread.title_full: Can we play you every week? Inside the world's smallest football league, which contains just TWO teams

author: Mark Jones
title: Can we play you every week? Inside the world's smallest football league, which contains just TWO teams
text:
Sport Can we play you every week? Inside the world's smallest football league, which contains just TWO teams The Isles of Scilly Football League is an unforgiving division, where coming second just isn't acceptable and local derbies are the norm Share The most regular of local derbies (Photo: Getty Images) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
While we might end up getting obsessed with the battle for top four in the Premier League , there is no such thing in the Isles of Scilly Football League. 
That's because the division - which is affiliated with the Football Association - has just TWO clubs in it. 
Woolpack Wanderers and Garrison Gunners meet on Sunday mornings during most weeks of the football season, battling against each other for supremacy in a division in which every match is a both a six-pointer in the title race and a clash to avoid coming bottom of the division. Garrison Gunners keeper Leigh Reeve makes a save (Photo: Getty Images) Woolpack Wanderers' Lewis Brown sees his effort blocked (Photo: Getty Images) 
The archipelago of five main inhabited islands some 28 miles off the Cornish peninsula is the sourthernmost part of the United Kingdom. 
There are just over 2,200 people there, with most of the properties on the island owned by the Duchy of Cornwall. The players head in at half-time at Garrison's home ground (Photo: Getty Images) Garrison Gunners' Tim Brook prepares for a match in his own unique way (Photo: Getty Images) 
The teams rarely have to worry about matches being called off, with the climate being much warmer than mainland Britain and therefore a popular tourist destination. 
The teams played out a 1-1 draw in the match pictured on February 19th, proving that their tiny league is certainly a competitive one. Woolpack Wanderers' Anthony Gibbons gets the pitch ready (Photo: Getty Images) Woolpack Wanderers have their half-time team talk (Photo: Getty Images) Matt Simons swings in a corner (Photo: Getty Images) 
We're not sure who's going to win the division this season, but we can be pretty confident of one thing. 
It'll be between one of two teams. 
Definitely.
